Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Modeling the Patterns of Past Human Migration during the Middle Bronze Age in Korea
Award.AbstractNarration:
Human migration has long been considered one of the major sources of impact on cultural expansion and changes in archaeology. Understanding of migrations become increasingly critical in current sociopolitical and economic situations where populations are migrating and interacting globally at an unprecedented rate. Relatively constricted concepts of past migrations as disconnected, passive events have come in for criticism. A new set of questions highlights the special relevance of migration not only to archaeological studies that concern how and why culture has changed, but also to social, ecological, and behavioral sciences that seek explanations on human choices and behaviors. This project will examine and model the patterns of human migration of the Songguk-ri (SGR) culture, a prehistoric Bronze Age culture, occurring between approx. 800 ? 400 BCE in Korea. By applying spatial landscape analysis using high-performance computation and simulation systems on SGR settlement patterns over time, the project will explore complex social and environmental factors, processes, and impacts behind long-term human migration. This project will be conducted at the Korean Institute of Archaeology and Environment (KIAE) at Korea University in collaboration with Dr. Lee, Hongjong and his research associates, noted scholars and pioneers in Environmental and Landscape Archaeological Science and its application in Korea.

This project will examine and model the patterns of human migration of the Songguk-ri (SGR) culture occurring during the Korean Middle Bronze Age (2800 ? 2400 cal. BP) in Korea through a spatial analytic perspective using Geographical Information System (GIS) and Agent-Based Modeling and Simulation (ABMS) on SGR settlement distribution. Since the SGR culture shows evidence of rapid and sustained human migration across various geographical and cultural barriers within the relatively short 400 years after its emergence, this case study on SGR expansion will contribute valuable insight to current understandings on complex social and environmental factors, processes, and impacts behind long-term human migration across preferred landscapes. This project will be conducted at the Korean Institute of Archaeology and Environment (KIAE) at Korea University in collaboration with Dr. Lee, Hongjong and his research associates, noted scholars and pioneers in Environmental and Landscape Archaeological Science and its application in Korea.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

From June 6th to August 6th, 2016, I have participated in East Asia Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) in Korea with Korea Institute of Archaeology and Environment (KIAE), Korea University as my host institution. My host was Dr. Lee, Hong Jong, the director and professor of the KIAE and the Department of Archaeology and Art History at Korea University.

My research topic during the EAPSI program revolved around the landscape study of the Songguk-ri culture. Songguk-ri culture is a prehistoric Bronze Age culture, occurring between approx. 800 and 400 BCE, in Korea. In Koran archaeology, Songguk-ri culture is commonly understood as one of the earliest societies with complex social organization and economic foundation on intensive rice agriculture. Songguk-ri culture first emerges in the southwestern region of Korea along the middle and lower reach of the Geum River approximately around 800 BCE. After its emergence, Songguk-ri culture rapidly expands southwards and occupied wide regions in south-central, south, and south-western regions of Korea. By 600 BCE, Songguk-ri culture groups navigated to Jeju Island, 120 km off the southwest coast of the Peninsula and northern Kyushu, Japan.

My study examine and model the patterns of human migration of Songguki-ri culture using geo-spatial analysis. Since Songguk-ri culture shows evidences of long-term human migration across various geographical and cultural barriers within the relatively short 400 years after its emergence, Songguk-ri cultural expansion can be an ideal case for the study of complex social and environmental factors, processes, and impacts behind long-term human migration. I believe geo-spatial analyses using geographical information system (GIS) can be a highly apt approach to holistically study complex factors and process behind Songguk-ri cultural expansion and social change through time. By providing computer-assisted methods of systematically store, visualize, compare, and analyze various information and relationships across time and space, GIS studies can utilize rich set of archaeological data available on Songguk-ri culture including radiocarbon dates, settlement location, and artifact and features types to shed new lights on Songguk-ri cultural expansion and social change through time.

As a cultural phenomenon, human migration is more than an event about movement of population across boundaries. Rather it is a long sociopolitical and ecological process involving complex cultural interactions leading to emergence of new idea, practice, and identity. My study on the Songguk-ri cultural expansion and migration has special relevance to the present society that is experiencing unprecedented rate of human migration and subsequent cultural interaction at a global scale in two major ways. First it can supply valuable long-term perspectives to the understandings on the cause, process, and impact of human migration from archaeological perspective. Second, it can bring important benefits of modeling exercise (Epstein 2008) such as guiding data collection, discovering new questions, disciplining policy dialogues, educating the general public, and lastly possibly predicting future patterns to the present society’s interface to the issue of human migration.

 

Research Outcome

My research outcome during EAPSI can be summarized into three research activities. First, I learned multiple geo-spatial analytic techniques such as geo-referencing site maps, and stereoscopic 3-D visualization of past landscape using aerial photos from Dr. Lee, Hong Jong and his research associates at KIAE. Second with logistic aids from Dr. Yun, Ho Pil at Jungbu Institute for Archaeology and Mr. Park Geun Tae at Jeju Archaeological Institute, I made field trips to prehistoric settlement sites with Songguk-ri type artifacts in South Chungcheong, South Jeolla, South Gyeungnam, and Jeju Provinces to observe and examine Songguk-ri culture’s landscape. In addition to landscape observation, I also tested theoretical viewshed (visibility) model at some of these sites to better understand the relationship between Songguk-ri culture’s large and small settlements. Third, I collected site maps, radiocarbon data, and artifact information relating to the Songguk-ri culture, which are published often in forms of paper-based site reports, from library collection at KIAE.

In addition, at the courtesy of arrangements made by the NSF-EAPSI program and the National Research Foundation (NRF) of Korea, EAPSI fellows including myself participated in various events and occasions that promoted cultural exchange between Korean and US scientific communities. I also have presented the outcome and progress of the my EAPSI project during August 5, 2016 at National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) Seoul Office, attended by other EAPSI fellows and NRF research associates. I believe that the scholarly connections that I made during my EAPSI project will be valuable as I pursue future collaborative research in Korea. Furthermore through my current and future researches, I hope that I can promote collaborative and synergetic research relationships between scientific communities in the US and Korea.

 

Citation

1. Epstein, Joshua M. 2008. Why Model?. Journal of Artificial Societies and Social Simulation vol. 11, no. 4 12.
